title: 2 Ways to Fix a Punctured Tire

steps.title: Locate the tire that is losing air.
steps.content: Locate the tire that is losing air. Remove your valve caps first. You can either find the hole by looking for the nail that is pierced through the tire, or you can put the tire in a tub of water and roll it around in driving rotation. There should be air bubbles where the hole is.

steps.title: Take the tire off from the rim.
steps.content: Take the tire off from the rim. This allows the puncture to be easily accessed. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Remove anything that's in the tire.
steps.content: Remove anything that's in the tire. If you have found the hole, and there is a nail punctured through it, use your pliers. Grab from the threading of the nail and lift out the nail. Mark the hole with tire chalk for easy access.

steps.title: Once the hole is clear, squirt some buffering solution over the puncture.
steps.content: Once the hole is clear, squirt some buffering solution over the puncture. This allows the buffer to work effectively and leave you with a smooth surface.

steps.title: Grab your buffer machine.
steps.content: Grab your buffer machine. Make sure that you have a sanding pad surface on your buffer to get a smooth surface. Buff all around the punctured area in a circular motion to make sure you get everywhere you need.

steps.title: Use a Tire Radial Patch.
steps.content: Use a Tire Radial Patch. You can start by first removing the sticky pads of the inner side of the Radial Patch. Then from the inside of the tire, you can stick the Radial Patch through the hole about halfway with the aluminum side first.

steps.title: Spread the Tire Chemical Care (Seal Fast B-133).
steps.content: Spread the Tire Chemical Care (Seal Fast B-133). Using the brush at the end of the cap, spread the liquid material all around the Radial Patch string as shown in the picture. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the rest of the Radial Patch through the tire.
steps.content: Pull the rest of the Radial Patch through the tire. You must pull all the way through until the patch completely sits on the inner side of the tire, and the aluminum piece comes out of the rubber.

steps.title: Cut the long leftover end of the patch using your cutting pliers.
steps.content: Cut the long leftover end of the patch using your cutting pliers. Scissors will work too. As shown in the picture, you want to cut as low as you can.

steps.title: Roll over the patch.
steps.content: Roll over the patch. Using your Tire Retread and Repair Tool, run over the Radial Patch from the inside of the tire. You can roll it in any direction, as long as you make sure to get every spot of the patch. Once the steps have been completed, your tire is ready to hit me back on the rims and filled to the pressure needed to be back on the road. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Locate the tire that is losing air.
steps.content: Locate the tire that is losing air. Remove your valve caps first. You can either find the hole by looking for the nail that is pierced through the tire, or you can put the tire in a tub of water and roll it around in driving rotation. There should be air bubbles where the hole is.

steps.title: Keep the tire on the rim and expand the hole.
steps.content: Keep the tire on the rim and expand the hole. Using the Pistol Grip Rasp Tool, you can insert it through the puncture moving it up and down. It will expand the hole if needed to fit the Tire Repair Refills in. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Spray Heavy Duty Silicone Lubricant over the punctured area.
steps.content: Spray Heavy Duty Silicone Lubricant over the punctured area.

steps.title: Grab the Pistol Grip Inserting Needle and take a piece of the Tire Repair Refills.
steps.content: Grab the Pistol Grip Inserting Needle and take a piece of the Tire Repair Refills. Put the Tire Repair Refills piece through the Needle as shown in the picture.

steps.title: When the refill piece is placed in between the needle, you can hold from the pistol grip and pierce the needle through the hole and pull the needle back out.
steps.content: When the refill piece is placed in between the needle, you can hold from the pistol grip and pierce the needle through the hole and pull the needle back out. The Tire Repair Refill piece should be left inside the hole. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Cut off the refill piece that is sticking out of the tire using the cutting pliers or even scissors.
steps.content: Cut off the refill piece that is sticking out of the tire using the cutting pliers or even scissors. [6] X Research source (If you have a lighter, you can even set the extra piece of the refill on fire).
